doc.title: Global Markets Daily: Searching for a in Asia Local High Yield Bonds; Stay Long PHP 5Y (FX hedged) (Swanapruti / Gedminas)
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/Global Markets Daily Searching for Value in Asia Local High Yield Bonds Stay Long PHP 5Y FX hedged Suwanapruti GedminasG_2025-08-28

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS

passages.text: We have been bullish on Asian loconds for most of this year, as regional central banks have been cutting rates. Despite our expectations for further monetary policy easing in H2- 2025 and into 2026, we think much of the rate cut expectations are well- priced in low yield markets. As such, we turn to our EM local rates fair value model and consider our refreshed macro assessments, as we look for value in Asian local high yield bond markets.

Our EM local rates fair value framework takes into account inflation, fiscal and external risks and global rate developments, and models them across the curve. After refreshing our latest macro inputs, which take into account a more dovish domestic backdrop, our model suggests that there is more value in Asian local currency high yield markets (than low yield markets). Within Asia, our model signals there is more value in PHP than IDR and INR bond markets.

The BSP cut rates today by 25bp to \(5.0\%\) , but turned less dovish than before. The bond supply/demand dynamics in the Philippines are favorable amid large bond maturities in August and September. The successful Retail Treasury Bond issuance of PHP 507bn (including debt switches), versus typical auction sizes of PHP 20- 30bn, takes the pressure off supply funding needs for the rest of the year. As such, we remain constructive on PHP 5Y local bonds in EM Asia.

We had been bullish on IDR bonds for most of this year, but recently closed our long 1Y SRBI recommendation as it had already rallied more than 100bp since inception. We think the BI will cut by another 50bp but it could take a pause if faced with IDR weakness. We think the RBI will cut by another 25bp in this cycle, although this is also well- priced. Meanwhile, mid- to long- end INR yields have been rising on fiscal concerns (in the event the government responds to the additional tariff drag on growth).

We have been bullish on Asian local bonds for most of this year, as regional central banks have been cutting rates on the back of falling inflation and weaker growth outlooks. Despite our expectations for further monetary policy easing across most Asian central banks (including the PBoC, BoK, CBC, RBI, BI, BoT, BSP and MAS) in H2- 2025 and into 2026 (Exhibit 1), we think that most of the rate cut expectations

are well priced in low yield markets. To search for where there is potentially still value in Asian local bond markets, we refresh our EM local rates fair value model and overlay this with our assessments on the latest macro developments and policy drivers.
Exhibit 1: Asian central banks have been in easing mode since 2024, with more cuts still to come
Source: Bloomberg, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 2: Our EM local rates fair value model indicates PHP 5Y has the most scope to rally among Asian high yielders
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Our EM local rates fair value framework takes into account inflation, fiscal and external risks and global rate developments, and models them across the curve for a spectrum of markets under our coverage. After refreshing the model, considering our latest macro inputs, for example the relatively benign inflation backdrop, suggests that there is more value in Asian local currency high yield markets (than low yield markets), as more benign inflation developments have provided domestic tailwinds for local currency fixed income markets. Within the three high yield local currency bond markets in Asia, we find that IDR and INR local have rallied through our fair value estimates, whereas even after the recent rally, the valuation signal points to scope for even more downside in yields for 5Y PHP bonds (with our fair value estimate at around \(5.50\%\) versus current yield of \(5.70\%\) ).

On the macro front, the Philippines central bank cut policy rates by another 25bp today to \(5.0\%\) , but turned less dovish than before. The BSP governor noted that the policy rate is at "goldilocks" level, but with the caveat that another rate cut is possible. Given our expectations for global growth to slow in H2- 2025 and our more dovish Fed outlook (versus marketing pricing), we think the BSP will deliver another two 25bp cuts (in Q4- 2025 and Q1- 2026) to reach a terminal rate of \(4.50\%\) . Meanwhile, bond supply/demand dynamics are very favorable. The Bureau of Treasury (BTR) sold PHP 507bn of Retail Treasury Bonds earlier this month (including PHP 82bn in debt switches), well above market expectations on strong demand. For context, typical auctions sizes in the Philippines are around PHP 20- 30bn. Separately, there was a large PHP 516bn maturity on the August 12, with another large maturity of PHP 289bn due on September 9, meaning that there has been a net injection of PHP liquidity via bond maturities. We note that Philippines local government bonds are being considered for potential inclusion in the GBI- EM Global Diversified Index, with the announcement due around September. We maintain our recommendation to go long PHP 5Y bonds (FX hedged) (entry \(5.93\%\) , target \(5.25\%\) , stop \(6.35\%\) , current \(5.70\%\) ).
We had been bullish on IDR bonds since October last year and had recommended being

long the 1Y SRBIs. However, with front- end yields having already moved over 110bp since inception and the trade hit our target, we decided to close the trade recommendation and shift to a neutral stance on IDR local government bonds. Bank Indonesia (BI) has cut rates six times since August 2024, from \(6.25\%\) to \(5.0\%\) currently. With July inflation at \(2.4\%\) yoy, comfortably within the BI's target range of \(1.5 - 3.5\%\) , we think the BI has scope to cut rates twice more (by 25bp each in September and Q4) to a terminal rate of \(4.90\%\) . However, we are not as constructive on IDR bonds (compared with PHP bonds) because Indonesian government bonds are already better- owned by foreign investors, IDR bond yields have already moved significantly and there is potentially more scope for the BSP to be do with than the BI, since the latter also has an explicit mandate on FX stability (meaning that the BI may be more inclined to pause easing in periods of currency weakness). Lastly, the GBI- EM Global Diversified Index is considering lowering the cap on market weights from \(10\%\) currently, to \(8.5\%\) . Given that Indonesia (along with China and India) is around the \(10\%\) cap, if this new weighting rule is applied, then this is likely to result in Indonesia's weight being lowered by around \(1.5\%\) (potentially worth around USD 3- 4bn of passive outflows). Given the above macro factors and our signals from our valuation models, we have a neutral stance on IDR government bonds.

Our India economics team revised down their 2025 real GDP growth forecasts to \(6.5\%\) yoy when the US imposed \(25\%\) reciprocal tariffs on India's exports to the US. This week, the US announced another \(25\%\) "ad valorem" tariff, citing India's continued energy purchases from Russia, taking total tariffs to \(50\%\) (the highest in all of Asia). Taking into account exemptions, we estimate that the total effective tariff rate on Indian exports to the US would be around \(32\%\) . Our economists had previously highlighted that, if implemented, they could pose a further potential drag to economic growth. We maintain our view that the RBI will cut its policy rate by another 25bp this year to \(5.25\%\) , although we acknowledge that risks are skewed to the dovish side, with the RBI Governor recently commenting that the central bank is ready to step in with policy measures to support growth if the \(50\%\) tariffs comes into effect. INR OIS front- end rates are pricing in around one cut in the next 12- months, which is in line with our forecast. Mid- (5Y) to long- end INR bond yields (10Y, 20Y, 30Y) have been rising on fiscal concerns (in the event the government steps in to support vulnerable groups impacted by tariffs). Given that we think front- end yields are well priced and long- end yields are rising, we have a neutral near- term outlook on INR bonds.
For pricing, charts, and a list of previous recommendations, please visit our Trade Ideas page.

1. Stay short THB/KRW, opened January 10, 2025, at 42.30, with a target of 39.0, and a stop of 44.0, currently trading at 42.96.  
2. Stay short USD/EGP, opened July 16, 2025, at 0.0%, with a total return target of
\(7.0\%\) and a revised stop of \(1.0\%\) , currently trading at \(3.4\%\) .

3. Stay short USD/JPY, opened August 1, 2025, at 147.69, with a target of 142 and a stop of 152, currently trading at 147.42.  
4. Stay long 20s on 10s20s30s weighted SOFR fly (weights 0.6x: 2x: 1.4x), opened August 1, 2025, at 0.24, with a target at 0.18 and a stop at 0.27, currently trading at 0.24.  
5. Stay long PHP 5Y bond FX-hedged, opened August 5, 2025, at 5.93%, with a target of \(5.25\%\) and a stop at \(6.35\%\) , trading at \(5.70\%\) .  
6. Receive 3Y IBR in Colombia, opened August 6, 2025, at 8.44%, with a target at \(8.00\%\) and a stop at \(8.70\%\) , currently trading at \(8.44\%\) .  
7. Stay long SFRZ5 vs ERZ5, opened August 8, 2025, at 1.84%, with a target at \(1.54\%\) and a stop at \(1.95\%\) , currently trading at \(1.82\%\) .  
8. Stay long 1m2y USD receiver vs sell A+10 payer (return in bp running), opened August 8, 2025 (payer added on August 15, 2025), at 0.06, with a target at 0.20 and a stop at -0.02, currently trading at 0.10.  
9. Stay long 3m2y A-25bp receiver vs short 3m5y A-25bp receiver (return in bp running), opened August 8, 2025, at 0.01, with a target at 0.15 and a stop at -0.05, currently trading at 0.01.  
10. Stay short EUR/CHF, opened August 8, 2025, at 0.9415, with a target at 0.9300 and a stop at 0.9475, currently trading at 0.9339.  
11. Receive Sept 2025 BoC meeting OIS, opened August 22, 2025, at 2.67%, with a target at \(2.55\%\) and a stop at \(2.72\%\) , currently trading at \(2.66\%\) .
